content:
Function: Data Import
Category: Data Management
Difficulty: Beginner

SPSS Data Import: To import data, go to File > Open > Data. Supported formats include .sav, .csv, .xlsx, .txt. For CSV files, ensure proper delimiter settings and variable names in first row.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. File > Open > Data
2. Select file format (.sav, .csv, .xlsx, .txt)
3. For CSV: Set delimiter and variable names
4. Click OK to import

Function: Variable Recoding
Category: Data Management
Difficulty: Intermediate

Variable Recoding: Use Transform > Recode > Into Different Variables to create new variables. Specify old and new values, handle missing data, and apply labels for clarity.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. Transform > Recode > Into Different Variables
2. Select source variable
3. Define old and new values
4. Handle missing data appropriately
5. Add variable labels

Function: Missing Data Analysis
Category: Data Management
Difficulty: Advanced

Missing Data Analysis: Use Analyze > Missing Value Analysis to identify patterns. Options include listwise deletion, pairwise deletion, or multiple imputation for handling missing values.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. Analyze > Missing Value Analysis
2. Select variables for analysis
3. Choose missing data handling method
4. Review patterns and decide on approach

Function: Descriptive Statistics
Category: Descriptive Statistics
Difficulty: Beginner

Descriptive Statistics: Use Analyze > Descriptive Statistics > Descriptives to get mean, standard deviation, minimum, maximum, and other summary statistics for continuous variables.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. Analyze > Descriptive Statistics > Descriptives
2. Select variables for analysis
3. Choose statistics (mean, std dev, min, max, etc.)
4. Click OK to run analysis

Function: Frequency Tables
Category: Descriptive Statistics
Difficulty: Beginner

Frequency Tables: Use Analyze > Descriptive Statistics > Frequencies to create frequency distributions for categorical variables. Include percentages, cumulative percentages, and charts.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. Analyze > Descriptive Statistics > Frequencies
2. Select categorical variables
3. Choose statistics (frequencies, percentages, charts)
4. Click OK to generate tables

Function: Independent Samples T-Test
Category: Inferential Statistics
Difficulty: Intermediate

T-Test (Independent Samples): Use Analyze > Compare Means > Independent-Samples T Test to compare means between two groups. Ensure variables meet assumptions of normality and equal variances.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. Analyze > Compare Means > Independent-Samples T Test
2. Select test variable (dependent variable)
3. Select grouping variable (independent variable)
4. Define groups (e.g., 1 and 2)
5. Click OK and interpret results

Function: One-Way ANOVA
Category: Inferential Statistics
Difficulty: Intermediate

One-Way ANOVA: Use Analyze > Compare Means > One-Way ANOVA to compare means across three or more groups. Check homogeneity of variances and normality assumptions.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. Analyze > Compare Means > One-Way ANOVA
2. Select dependent variable
3. Select factor (independent variable)
4. Set confidence level (default 95%)
5. Click OK and check F-statistic and p-value

Function: Correlation Analysis
Category: Inferential Statistics
Difficulty: Intermediate

Correlation Analysis: Use Analyze > Correlate > Bivariate to examine relationships between variables. Choose correlation coefficient (Pearson, Spearman) based on data type and distribution.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. Analyze > Correlate > Bivariate
2. Select variables for correlation
3. Choose correlation coefficient
4. Set significance level
5. Click OK and interpret correlation matrix

Function: Linear Regression
Category: Regression Analysis
Difficulty: Advanced

Linear Regression: Use Analyze > Regression > Linear to predict dependent variable from independent variables. Check assumptions: linearity, normality, homoscedasticity, and independence.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. Analyze > Regression > Linear
2. Select dependent variable
3. Select independent variables
4. Choose method (Enter, Stepwise, etc.)
5. Check assumptions and interpret results

Function: Multiple Regression
Category: Regression Analysis
Difficulty: Advanced

Multiple Regression: Use Analyze > Regression > Linear for multiple predictors. Consider multicollinearity, use stepwise selection if needed, and validate model assumptions.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. Analyze > Regression > Linear
2. Select dependent variable
3. Add multiple independent variables
4. Check for multicollinearity (VIF)
5. Validate assumptions and interpret model

Function: Factor Analysis
Category: Factor Analysis
Difficulty: Advanced

Factor Analysis: Use Analyze > Dimension Reduction > Factor to identify underlying latent variables. Check KMO, Bartlett's test, and use appropriate rotation methods.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. Analyze > Dimension Reduction > Factor
2. Select variables for analysis
3. Choose extraction method (Principal Components)
4. Select rotation method (Varimax, Oblimin)
5. Interpret factor loadings and communalities

Function: Chi-Square Test
Category: Nonparametric Tests
Difficulty: Intermediate

Chi-Square Test: Use Analyze > Nonparametric Tests > Chi-Square to test independence between categorical variables. Ensure expected frequencies are adequate (>5).

Step-by-Step Process:
1. Analyze > Nonparametric Tests > Chi-Square
2. Select test variables
3. Check expected frequencies
4. Click OK and interpret chi-square statistic
5. Check p-value for significance

Function: Mann-Whitney U Test
Category: Nonparametric Tests
Difficulty: Intermediate

Mann-Whitney U Test: Use Analyze > Nonparametric Tests > Independent Samples to compare two groups when data doesn't meet t-test assumptions.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. Analyze > Nonparametric Tests > Independent Samples
2. Select test variables
3. Define groups
4. Choose Mann-Whitney U test
5. Interpret U statistic and p-value

Function: Histograms
Category: Data Visualization
Difficulty: Beginner

Histograms: Use Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Histogram to visualize distribution of continuous variables. Check for normality, skewness, and outliers.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Histogram
2. Select variable for histogram
3. Choose display options (normal curve, etc.)
4. Click OK to generate chart

Function: Scatter Plots
Category: Data Visualization
Difficulty: Beginner

Scatter Plots: Use Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Scatter/Dot to examine relationships between two continuous variables. Add regression line if appropriate.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. Graphs > Legacy Dialogs > Scatter/Dot
2. Select X and Y variables
3. Choose scatter plot type
4. Add regression line if needed
5. Click OK to generate plot

Function: Output Management
Category: Output and Reporting
Difficulty: Beginner

SPSS Output: Results appear in Output Viewer. Right-click to copy, export as Word/Excel, or save as .spv file. Use Edit > Options to customize output format.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. View results in Output Viewer
2. Right-click to copy or export
3. File > Export to save in different formats
4. Edit > Options to customize display

Function: Syntax Editor
Category: Output and Reporting
Difficulty: Advanced

Syntax Editor: Use File > New > Syntax to write and save SPSS commands. Syntax provides reproducibility and automation for complex analyses.

Step-by-Step Process:
1. File > New > Syntax
2. Write SPSS commands
3. Use Run > All to execute
4. Save .sps file for future use
